clues.text: "Take me down to" this Guns N' Roses song "where the grass is green & the girls are pretty, oh won't you please take me home"
A 1991 compilation album by this Sixx-shooting band looked back at a "Decade of Decadence"
Deadly on Billboard, this hair metal band had Top 10s with "Talk Dirty To Me" & "Unskinny Bop"
"Here I Go Again", talking about Tawny Kitaen's acrobatics on David Coverdale's Jaguar hood in a classic video by this group
Rolling Stone gave us an oral history of this song by Extreme, "1991's iconic ballad"; now hold me close, don't ev-ah let me go

A couple of the apothecary type of these weigh 960 grains:
USE CON

It's 6.35 kilograms:
NOTES

It's used to account for extremely small particles:
ROMAN NAG

10 Talmudic these equaled 600 minas back in the day:
LETS TAN

It makes quite the system:
ADIOS OUR VIP
Terlingua has been called one of Texas' most famous one of these 2-word sites, a specter of its heyday as a hub for mining cinnabar
Daniel Boone National Forest & the International Museum of the Horse can be found in this state
This lake in Idaho comes from French for "heart of an awl"
This hah-bah on Mount Desert Island in Maine is called "the Gateway to Acadia National Park"
This state is not famous as a source of jazz talent, but Bix Beiderbecke was born there
This playground pavement game has a potent potable in its name
This adjective deals with the creation & use of low-temperature phenomena
In the U.S., form N-400 is an application for this process that may also require fingerprints
Type of container meaning "2-handled" & often holding wine; the Acropolis museum has a 3,400-year-old one
It's the term for a blank page found at either the beginning or the end of a book
This Pulitzer Prize winner was hit & killed in 1949 as she tried to cross Peachtree Street in Atlanta
He died in 1984 at the home of Johnny Carson's ex-wife Joanne, not one of his swans but a close friend to the end
This author from Sauk Centre, Minnesota died in a nursing home in Rome in 1951
A friend of Shakespeare, this "Song: To Celia" poet & playwright was buried standing up in Westminster Abbey
Legend has it that this ancient playwright died when an eagle dropped a tortoise on his head
An economic surplus or oversupply; in 2015 there was a worldwide one of crude oil, sending prices down
In the 19-teens one company had a monopoly on this invention that taught us to say "cha-ching"
Lines 2 & 3 of this Shakespeare play are "Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting, The appetite may sicken, and so die"
This king lost his treasure in a bay called the Wash & provoked the barons with too much taxation
At the center of the 1980s era of excess, this Spanish resort is supposed to have gotten its name from an exclamation of "Beautiful sea!"

rounds.comments: (Ken: Each response is a series of letters that would average out to the GPA we give you, the grade point average.)

clues.text:
2.0:
Lazarus Naturals makes creams & gummies out of it

3.0:
It's on a blackboard in "Glengarry Glen Ross"

2.75:
Immigration policy program announced June 15, 2012

3.6:
Limerick rhyme scheme

1.75:
This body wants to win back the House of Representatives
It traces its roots to the founding of the International Committee for the Relief of the Wounded in 1863
In 1873 this shipping magnate donated $1 million to endow a Nashville university; guess who the university is named for
At this 1805 naval battle, Lord Nelson gave his famous signal, "England expects that every man will do his duty"
Spain's second queen of this name ruled from 1833 until 1868, when a revolution forced her into exile
The Treaty of Nanjing in 1842 ended the first of these wars instigated by British drug dealers
In the 1950s a 12-year-old boy went to Columbus & got this state's lawmakers to adopt "With God All Things Are Possible"
In 2006, 50 years after the United States made it official, Florida made it the state motto as well
Kentucky's motto, "United We Stand" followed by these 3 words, has a lengthy history dating as far back as Aesop
L'etoile du Nord, or "star of the north", isn't the motto of Alaska but this state that's the northernmost of the lower 48
Tennessee's motto has the names of these 2 cabinet departments, one about sowing & one about selling
These 2 adjectives describe the night in the much-parodied opening line of the 1830 novel "Paul Clifford"
This term for a period of supposed stagnation beginning around 500 A.D. is based on a 14th century passage by Petrarch
These ancient texts discovered in 1947 contain an account of an impending war between the Sons of Light & the Sons of Darkness
Often called the first dark horse president, this 11th chief executive waged the Mexican War & added vast new territory to the USA
In 1933 astronomer Fritz Zwicky posited the existence of this, detected only by its gravitational effects
"The Red Death" created by this 19th century author was a disease that killed people a half-hour from onset
In "Little Women", the hands of this character "seemed too feeble to hold even the rosy little shells they had been collecting"
The title of this Rachael Lippincott bestseller was a distance kept by 2 sick teens, cutting the recommended boundary by a foot
In Philip Roth's "Nemesis", an epidemic of this viral disease hits kids in Newark in 1944 before the vaccine is developed
This author opens with "The Death of Ivan Ilych", then works backward as we see how Ivan got there
This author followed 1897's "The Invisible Man" with 1898's "The War of the Worlds"
He gave Jenny Lind the nickname "The Swedish Nightingale" & risked his fortune to bring her to the U.S. for a tour
He succeeded P.W. Botha as the president of South Africa
This sociologist was the first African-American person to get a Ph.D. from Harvard
The cantata "Iphigenia in Brooklyn" was composed by Peter Schickele under this name

rounds.text: Jebel Musa in Morocco & Mount Hacho near Ceuta are candidates for the southern half of this pair
